subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’d
like to share with you some reflections
about my old friend Jacques Valle and the
birth of the world wide web.
You know, Jacques, many of you know is the
figure after whom the French scientist
in the movie Close Encounters of the
Third Kind, Steven Spielberg’s
blockbuster movie.
Well, that character, the French scientist,
was based on Jacques Vallee. He is a
mythical figure, virtually, in the field
of Ufology, the study of UFOs. He has
published many books in that area and is
really regarded as a foremost thinker in
that area. I did my first interview with
Jacques back in 1973. So, I’ve known him
and followed his work for nearly half a
century. What most people don’t know
about Jacques Valle, people who are
aware of his work in the UFO field are
not necessarily aware of the fact that
he’s a computer scientist, an astro-
physicist, and has also been engaged in
parapsychology research for a long time.
In fact, not only a computer
scientist, he was part of the team that
developed the ARPANET which really was
the basis of what we call the internet
today. He did some of the original
software development on the ARPANET.
He remembers that time well. In fact, I
just finished listening to Jacques
deliver a keynote address to the
Parapsychological Association’s annual
conference. It's interesting because when
I first published my book The Roots of
Consciousness in 1975 I emphasized the
relationship between UFOs and
parapsychology because I thought it was
pretty
well obvious. Here in the West coast
amongst parapsychologists who were
familiar with Jacques, that’s true.
But on the East coast the parapsychology
community to some degree took umbrage to
the idea that parapsychology should in
any way be associated with UFOs. It has
to do with the schism in parapsychology
that I have addressed actually in a
recent “InPresence” monologue. But that's
a parenthetical point because yesterday
Jacques was the honored keynote speaker
at the Parapsychological Association, so
I think you can say the zeitgeist is
shifting in more ways than one.
The point that Jacques made, and I should
say this, he’s also a futurist. In fact he
worked for, as I recall,
The Institute for the Future. He was a
venture capitalist, a man of many talents.
He gave a talk on parapsychology and
software computer technology,
interestingly enough. He went into the
history of the internet. Because, you
can imagine, if you are Jacques Vallee
working at SRI International, a huge $200
million dollar military industrial
think tank, back in the days when $200
million was real money. He was
working on the ARPANET, the very first
computer network. In fact, the computer
at SRI that he was working with was
the second computer linked into the
ARPANET. Eventually it grew to about 50 and
that's where he experimented with the
software required to create, really,
what amounts to the world’s first social
network. At the same time, he was also
friends with Hal Puthoff and Russell
Targ who were doing remote viewing
research with the psychic Ingo Swann at
SRI. Jacques knew that both of these
developments were revolutionary, could
change society
dramatically. Looking back he could
see, well, the internet fulfilled that
promise. He
was working on it
in the early 1970’s, nearly 50 years ago.
If you look at the internet and what
it's done over the last 50 years, why,
virtually everybody’s life has changed
because of it. Or certainly, most people,
all over the world. And yet,
parapsychology... well, 50 years ago, the
Parapsychological Association was
formally affiliated with the American
Association for the Advancement of
Science, giving it real scientific
credibility and recognition. One
would have thought, wow that's the birth
of a new era. Fifty years later we can
look back and say, things go much more
slowly in the field of parapsychology
because frankly, the paradigm, the
underlying philosophical assumptions,
even the unconscious assumptions
associated with parapsychology are that
much deeper than the ones associated
with a computer network. You can
understand a computer network with, you
know, common sense engineering and
physics. Parapsychology seems to defy
these things. But here's an interesting
bit of history. Back in the early days of
the first social network, Jacques Vallee
wanted to see if scientists at different
locations could work together on an
experiment? Would the computer
network he was developing be useful
as a tool for amplifying the intellect
of different scientists working in
different locations. He needed to do
a test and got funding to do the test.
His superiors at SRI International
where he was suggested, why doesn't he do
a test of some experiment he could
never get funded any other way,
because it was just a proof of concept.
He chose to do a psychic experiment.
He had Ingo Swan involved. It was a
remote viewing study using different
minerals. Hal Puthofff, Russell
Targ were involved, Arthur Hastings and
other parapsychologists, a number of other
remote viewers from the SRI program.
They did this study back in the early
1970s. The experiment showed some mild
evidence of ESP. Ingo Swan did great and
Richard Bach, the author of Jonathan
Livingston Seagull was one of the
participants and he did a great job. The
others not so much. Overall, it
was statistically significant. So, the
proof of concept that you could have an
internet that could be useful for
scientists working together was actually
developed based on a
parapsychology experiment. Isn't that
interesting? The other interesting
thing to note is how far the internet
has grown since the early 1970s, since
the first 50 computers were hooked up
together and how slow progress has been
in parapsychology in the same period of
time. But now, after 50 years since
AAAS has recognized the
Parapsychological Association, we see
that the American Psychological
Association now has granted a major form
of recognition in terms of Etzel
Cardena’s recent meta-analysis that was
published. A meta-analysis of meta-
analyses. He surveyed all the meta-
analyses in published journals,
refereed journals in the field of
parapsychology, I mentioned this
earlier: a total of over 1,700 published
studies with enormous statistical
significance and good methodology.
Now,
any psychologist... and psychologists are
used to pooh-poohing the field, they’re
going to have a hard time pooh-poohing the
field when all of this data has been
published in their flagship journal. I
think this is an important landmark. But
now I’m getting to the point I really
want to make. It was made by Jacques
Vallee in his keynote address, in which
looking at it as a futurist he said this,
“If you want to know what's going to
happen in the next 10 years, take a look
50 years ago and look at what has
happened over the last 50 because you
can project the progress from the last
50 years forward into the next 10.” I
feel optimistic at this point in time
that we are about to see a resurgence of
interest. It won't necessarily have to do
with the word parapsychology or esoteric
or psychic or anything like that because
we’re at a point now, historically
where many, many different fields,
everything from information science,
computer science, neuroscience, historical
studies, and of course quantum physics
are all looking at the role of
consciousness, the role of the observer.
Back, I think in the 1930s, Max Plank,
the great founder of quantum
physics said that consciousness is
underneath everything, you can't get
beyond consciousness. If it weren't
for consciousness you wouldn't be
viewing me right now and I wouldn’t be
having this experience of communicating
to you. I did a quick Google search on
online courses in psychic development.
Fifteen million came up; online parapsychology
courses, over 4000
Google listings. So, something is happening.
That's a point Jacques Vallee made is
that from the very beginning, computer
scientists,
people working in social networking and
in the web have always understood the
potential for coincidences to occur. I’ll
give you an example of one that I found
quite striking that has occurred right in
the context of this particular “In
Presence” monologue series. Some weeks ago
after I posted my very first monologue,
well it wasn't a monologue, it was karaoke,
singing karaoke... Mustang Sally and a
bunch of other songs. One of the viewers
posted a bunch of comments saying, how about Nessun
Dorma? Now, I have never heard of Nessun
Dorma, but it's an opera, an aria,
as I recall from Pucini - the opera, if
I remember correctly. In any case, I’d
never heard of it.
But then, a day later my wife and I
started reading a book. I'm showing the
book cover right now because I don't
even remember the title, but you'll see
it, it's a bestseller, a great book.
Ironically, the music Nessun Dorma, this
opera aria plays a key role in that book.
Now, it's not exactly a Jungian
synchronicity in the sense that it didn't
occur in the moment by
moment I posted the video that
Soteriologist, the viewer, posted his comment
about Nessun Dorma, it was a couple of
days before I started reading the book
in which Nessun Dorma was so prominent.
But I think of it as a synchronicity,
even though the time gap wasn’t
instantaneous. Well, I’m rambling
on. What's in all of this for you? The
connection between parapsychology and
the internet? My feeling, my
strong feeling that we're about to see a
surge in interest in parapsychology and
the paranormal much the way we
experienced 50 years ago
in the 1970s. What does that mean for you?
Once again, the answer will be individual.
So, I ask you to ponder that question.
Thank you for being with me.
[credits]
